block.p: Ruling by Arbitrator Splits Arthur Andersen in Two An international arbitrator ruled that the world's largest consulting firm could separate from the the world's largest accounting firm.

The ruling frees Andersen Consulting, with 65,000 employees, from its parent company, which now consists entirely of Arthur Andersen, a tax and auditing firm with 77,000 employees. In exchange, Andersen Consulting will have to give up its name and pay Arthur Andersen $1 billion. Analysts called the decision, coming at the end of a three-year battle, a major victory for the consultants. [Page A1.]

Bear Stearns Settles a Lawsuit Bear Stearns, the sixth-biggest United States securities firm, paid $30 million to settle a lawsuit over its role as an adviser on an ill-fated takeover, said lawyers involved in the case. The case sent tremors through Wall Street two years ago when a federal jury in California found the firm was negligent in the way it advised its client, Daisy Systems, on a 1989 purchase of Cadnetix, and awarded $108 million in damages to shareholders. The judge later reduced the award to $36 million. [C2.]

Two Millstone Reactors to Be Sold Dominion Resources said it was buying Northeast Utilities' two nuclear reactors at Millstone Point, near New London, Conn., for $1.3 billion, in what the buyers said was a record price for a nuclear plant. [C2.]

ABC to Correct Organic Food Story ABC News said a report it showed twice, challenging the assumed benefits of organic food, was based in part on research that did not exist. ABC said it would issue a correction during ''20/20'' on Friday night. In the report, the correspondent John Stossel said that research commissioned by ABC showed that conventional produce does not necessarily have more pesticide residue than organic produce. [C11.]

Stocks Rise on Interest Rate Hopes Stocks rose for a third day on optimism the economy is slowing enough that the Federal Reserve will not raise interest rates again in 2000. The Nasdaq composite index climbed 75.63 points, or 2 percent, to 3,862.99. The S.& P. 500 rose 16.39 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,479.32. And the Dow Jones industrial average gained 99.26 points, or 0.9 percent, to 10,867.01. [C11.]

Computer Associates to Revamp Computer Associates International, seeking to bolster its sagging stock, reassigned senior managers and said it intended to use spinoffs or other strategies to tap the value of fast-growing units now overshadowed by the company's main businesses. Charles B. Wang is turning over the job of chief executive to Sanjay Kumar, who had been president and chief operating officer. Mr. Wang will continue as chairman. Computer Associates shares have fallen from their 52-week high of $79.4375 to below $24 last week. [C6.]

Cisneros Is Leaving Univision Henry G. Cisneros, the former Housing Secretary in the Clinton administration who became president and chief operating officer of Univision Communications, the largest Spanish-language television broadcaster in the United States, announced that he was leaving after three and a half years ago to run a company that will build affordable housing in downtown areas. [C8.]

Earnings Fall at British Airways British Airways reported a 65 percent plunge in quarterly earnings, attributing the poor performance to the effects of the strong British pound and the rising price of jet fuel. The airline is trying to break out of a prolonged slump, partly through a proposed deal to acquire KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. But there were signs that those negotiations have not advanced very far. [C4.]
